> The other reason for using Lua is that its really
> really small,
> rediculously easy to embed, fully extendable with
> C/C++ functions, and
> compiles on every platform that has a
> standards-compliant C or C++
> compiler. Python might be all that too, though
> (except small, but that's
> forgivable).

As far as I can tell, Lua *is* C/C++. Python is
basically C/C++/Java with leaner syntax, a *lot* of
caring about whitespace (this is a weakness that I am
willing to admit), really crazy container/group types,
and generators thrown into the mix. It's really your
decision, and something that looks *exactly* like
C/C++ would probably be easier for the general
population.

> > Sorry, I've no SDL experience. ;-(
> 
> Its not too late! Grab a book on SDL and get
> crackin'! :-)

I'm moving into college (University of California
Irvine, in the same city that Blizzard is in) in two
days. I know for a fact that the student discount
doesn't work on O'Reilly books. ;-(
